verses.verse: (1 Thereof he inferreth, that good heed must be given to Christ’s doctrine:9 And he setteth him out unto us even as our brother in our flesh, that we may with a good will yield up ourselves wholly unto him.) Wherefore (Now as it were pausing with himself and showing to what end and purpose all these things were spoken, to wit, to understand by the excellency of Christ above all creatures, that his doctrine, majesty and Priesthood is most perfect, he useth an exhortation taken from a comparison.) we ought diligently to give heed to the things which (He maketh himself an hearer.) we have heard, lest at any time we (They are said to let the word run out, which hold it not fast when they have heard it.) run out.

For if the (The Law which appointed punishment for the offenders: and which Paul saith was given by Angels, Gal. 3:19, and Stephen, Acts 7:53.) word spoken by Angels was steadfast, and every transgression, and disobedience received a just recompense of reward,

How shall we escape if we neglect so great salvation, (If the breach and trangression of the word spoken by Angels was not suffered unpunished, much less shall it be lawful for us to neglect the Gospel which the Lord of Angels preached, and was confirmed by the voice of the Apostles, and with so many signs and wonders from heaven, and especially with so great and mighty working of the holy Ghost.) which at the first began to be preached by the Lord, and afterward was confirmed unto us by (By the Apostles.) them that heard him.

(Cross references: : Mark 16:20) God bearing witness thereto, both with (This is the true end of miracles. Now they are called signs, because they appear one thing, and represent another: and they are called wonders, because they represent some strange and unaccustomed things and virtues, because they give us a glimpse of God’s mighty power.) signs and wonders, and with divers miracles, and gifts of the holy Ghost, according to his own will?

(If it were an heinous matter to contemn the Angels which are but servants, much more heinous is it to contemn that most mighty King of the restored world.) For he hath not put in subjection unto the Angels the (The world to come, whereof Christ is Father, Isa. 9:6, or the Church, which as a new world, was to be gathered together by the Gospel.) world to come, whereof we speak.

(He showeth that the use of this kingly dignity consisteth herein, that men might not only [in] Christ recover that dignity which they have lost, but also might be through him advanced above all things, which dignity of men David describeth most excellently.) But (Ps. 8:6) one in a certain place witnessed, saying, (What is there in man that thou shouldest have so great regard of him, and do him that honor?) What is man, that thou shouldest be mindful of him? or the (He calleth all the citizens of that heavenly kingdom as they are considered in themselves, before that God giveth them the liberty, of that city in Christ, Man, and Son of man.) son of man, that thou wouldest consider him?

Thou (This is the first honor of the citizens of the world to come, that they are next [to] the Angels.) madest him a little inferior to the Angels: thou crownedst him with (For they shall be in very great honor, when they shall be partakers of the kingdom. And he speaketh of the thing that shall be, as though it were already, because it is so certain.) glory and honor, and hast set him above the works of thine hands.

(1 Cor. 15:27) Thou hast put all things in subjection under his feet. And in that he hath put all things in subjection under him, he left nothing that should not be subject unto him. (An objection: But where is this so great rule and dominion?) But we yet see not all things subdued unto him,

(The answer: this is already fulfilled in Jesus Christ our head, who was for a time for our sakes inferior to the Angels, being made man: but now is advanced into most high glory.) But we (By his virtue and power which appeareth manifestly in the Church.) see Jesus crowned with glory and honor, (Phil. 2:8) which was made little (Who abased himself for a season, and took upon him the position of a servant.) inferior to the Angels, (He showeth the cause of this subjection, to wit, to taste of death for our sakes, that so doing the part of a redeemer, he might not only be our Prophet and King, but also our high Priest.) through the (That he might die.) suffering of death, that by God’s grace he might (Feel death.) taste death for (Herein consisteth the force of the argument: for we could not at length be glorified with him, unless he was abased for us even all the faithful. And by this occasion the Apostle cometh to the other part of the declaration of Christ’s person, wherein he proveth him to be in such sort God, and he is also man.) all men.

(He proveth moreover by other arguments, why it behooveth the Son of God who is true God (as he proveth a little before) to become man notwithstanding, subject to all miseries, sin only except.) For it became (God.) him, for whom are all these things, and by whom are all these things, (First of all, because the Father, to whose glory all these things are to be referred, purposed to bring many sons unto glory. And how could he have men for his sons, unless his only begotten Son had become brother to men?) seeing that he brought many children unto glory, (Secondly, The Father determined to bring those sons to glory, to wit, out of that ignominy wherein they lay before. Therefore the Son should not have been seen plainly to be made man, unless he had been made like unto other men, that he might come to glory in the selfsame way, by which he should bring others: yea rather, it became him which was Prince of the salvation of others, to be consecrated above others, through those afflictions, Prophet, King, and Priest, which are the parts of that principality for the salvation of others.) that he should consecrate the (The Chieftain, who as he is chiefest in dignity, so is he the first begotten from among the dead, amongst many brethren.) Prince of their salvation through afflictions.

(The ground of both the former arguments: for neither should we be sons through him, neither could he be consecrated through afflictions, unless he hath been made man like unto us. But because this Sonhood dependeth not upon nature only, for no man is accompted the son of God, unless that besides that he is a son of a man, he be also Christ’s brother, (which is by sanctification, that is, by becoming one with Christ, who sanctifieth us through faith) therefore the Apostle maketh mention of the sanctifier, to wit, of Christ, and of them that are sanctified, to wit, of all the faithful, whom therefore Christ vouchsafeth to call brethren.) For he that (He useth the time that now is, to show us that we are yet still going on, and increasing in this sanctification, and by sanctification he meaneth our separation from the rest of the world, our cleansing from sin, and our dedication wholly unto God, all which Christ alone worketh in us.) sanctifieth, and they which are sanctified, are all of (One, of one selfsame nature of man.) one: wherefore he is not ashamed to call them brethren,

(That which he taught before of the incarnation of the sanctifier, he applieth to the prophetical office.) Saying, (Ps. 22:25) I will declare thy Name unto my brethren: in the midst of the Church will I sing praises to thee.

(He applieth the same to the kingly power of Christ in delivering his from the power of the devil and death.) And again, (Ps. 18:2) I will put my (I will commit myself to him, and to his defense.) trust in him. And again, Behold, here am I, and the children which God hath given me. (This Isaiah speaketh of himself and his disciples, but betokening thereby all ministers, as also his disciples signify the whole Church. And therefore seeing Christ is the head of the Prophets and ministers, these words are more rightly verified of him, than of Isaiah.) (Isa. 1:18)

Forasmuch then as the children are (Are made of flesh and blood which is a frail and brittle nature.) partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself likewise took part with them, that he might destroy (Hos. 13:14; 1 Cor. 15:55) through death, him that had the (The devil is said to have the power of death, because he is the author of sin: and from sin cometh death, and for this cause he eggeth us daily to sin.) power of death, that is, the (He speaketh of one as of the Prince, joining to him secretly all his angels.) devil,

And that he might deliver all them, which for fear of (By (death) thou must understand here that death which is joined with the wrath of God, as it must needs be, if it be without Christ, then there can be nothing devised more miserable.) death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.

(He expoundeth those words of flesh and blood, showing that Christ is true man, and not by turning his divine nature, but by taking on man’s nature. And he nameth Abraham, respecting the promises made to Abraham in this behalf.) For he in no sort took on him the (The nature of Angels.) Angels’ nature, but he took on him the (The very nature of man.) seed of Abraham.

(He applieth the same to the Priesthood, for which he should not have benefit, unless he had become man, and that like unto us in all things, sin only except.) Wherefore in (Not only as touching nature, but qualities also.) all things it behooved him to be made like unto his brethren, that he might be (That he might be truly touched with the feeling of our miseries.) merciful, and a (Doing his office sincerely.) faithful high Priest in things concerning God, that he might make reconciliation for the sins of the people.
For in that he suffered, and was (Was tried and egged to wickedness by the devil.) tempted, he is able to succor them that are tempted.
